metadata.title: Dupuytren’s Contracture  Occupational Therapy
anatomical location body part affected: Musculoskeletal system (hand); palmar fascia; metacarpophalangeal (MCP), proximal interphalangeal (PIP), and rarely distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints; most commonly affects the 4th, 5th digits
description: Contracture of palmar fascia, resulting in flexion deformities of the digit(s) and loss of function(27)

Dupuytren’s diathesis (features that predispose a person to have the disease and increase likelihood of recurrence):(2,14) –Early onset of disease (< 40 years) –Bilateral involvement –Ectopic lesions (knuckle pads, fascia plantaris, penile fascia) –Positive family history
For more information on Dupuytren’s contracture, see Clinical Review…Dupuytren’ s Disease; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708625

ICD-10 codes.M72.0: palmar fascial fibromatosis (Dupuytren’s) (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Firm nodule in palm of hand, proximal to MCP joint, close to distal palmar crease and in axis of 4th digit/ring finger(27)
Nodules are usually painless, then harden into a cord that extends into finger
Flexion contractures of the MCP and PIP joints of the ring and little fingers are most commonly observed. The thumb and index web space is also susceptible to developing contractures(2)
Skin changes, such as thickening of palmar skin and underlying subcutaneous tissue(26)

Secondary findings (estimated to occur in < 1% of patients with Dupuytren’s contracture)(27) –Knuckle pads (Garrod’s nodes) –Plantar fascial disease  –Contracture of penile fascial envelope (Peyronie disease) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors complicationsIncrease knowledge of complicationsPatient education _ Provide patient and/or caregiver with written instructions for signs/ symptoms to watch for following surgeryN/A Provide patient and/or caregiver with written instructions for signs/ symptoms to watch for following surgery . Desired Outcomes/Outcome Measures
contraindications precautions to test: Follow surgeon’s guidelines for postsurgical orthosis use, treatment
Keep incision from surgery clean and dry to prevent infection unless otherwise specified by surgeon (e.g., wet-dry dressings may be appropriate for a patient with an open palm)

causes: Possibly related to an increase in angiogenic basic fibroblast growth factor (bFGF)(27)
Genetic predisposition; believed to be inherited as autosomal dominant trait(26)
Possibly related to an increased level of tumor necrosis factor in patients undergoing BRAF inhibitor treatment formelanoma(5)
pathogenesis: Dupuytren’s fascia contains high concentrations of type III collagen, a high ratio of type III to type I collagen, increasedamounts of total collagen, and increased lysyl oxidase activity(3)
Local ischemia at microvascular level stimulates increased production of fibroblasts(3)
Fibroblasts organized along lines of mechanical stress, causing cord found in Dupuytren’s contracture(3)

Development of myofibroblasts(27)–In the proliferative stage, myofibroblasts increase(27)–In the residual stage, a dense fibroblast network is present(27)–In the involutional stage, myofibroblasts disappear, replaced by fibrous tissue and a cord-like  structure(27)
risk factors: Smoking (especially if been smoking for an average of 16 years)(27)
Use of cigarettes and alcohol together may increase risk(27)
Race/ethnic background: Northern European, Japanese, Taiwanese(27)

Vibration work exposure(27)–Authors of a cross-sectional  survey in Great Britain looking at the association between hand-transmitted  vibration andDupuytren’s contracture found an increased risk for contractures in men exposed to high levels of vibration on a weeklybasis(21)
May be associated with systemic fibrosing syndrome (e.g., Peyronie disease, mediastinal and retroperitoneal fibrosis,Riedel struma, and plantar fibromatosis)(16)

overall contraindications precautions: Exercise can increase flare-ups  of Dupuytren’s contracture(18)

Complex regional pain syndrome (CRPS) can be a complication following Dupuytren’s contracture release. If this occurs, treatment should focus on CRPS. Passive ROM (PROM) is contraindicated because of pain; splinting may also need to be discontinued temporarily until CRPS symptoms are controlled;(23) functional hand use (as tolerated by the patient) should continue to be encouraged. (For more information on CRPS, see Clinical Review…Complex Regional Pain Syndrome; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708498)
Follow surgeon’s guidelines for postsurgical orthosis use, wound care (e.g., wet-to-dry  dressings, whirlpool debridement), and treatment
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

contraindications precautions to examina: Follow surgeon’s guidelines for postsurgical orthosis use, treatment
Keep incision from surgery clean and dry to prevent infection unless otherwise specified by surgeon (e.g., wet-dry dressings may be appropriate for a patient with an open palm)

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Document when symptoms started, progression of symptoms, and nature of referral (postoperative versus nonoperative management)

course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications clinician has prescribed. Are they being taken? Are they effective? First-line  of treatment may be steroid injection (triamcinolone).(27) A potential complication of injection therapy is injury to nearby structures such as arteries, nerves, or flexor tendons 5-fluorouracil(27) Topical dimethyl sulfoxide(26) Colchicine(26) Interferon(26) Topical imiquimod (Aldara)(26) Oral simvastatin(27) Injectable collagenase ( Clostridium histolyticum )(1,16,25) or triamcinolone(16) Following injection and finger manipulation, skin tears may occur.(1) In these cases therapy will include wound management activities
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed: Although the diagnosis is typically based on clinical examination, possible additional tests for this condition include the following:
MRI (to assess vascularity of lesions) or ultrasound may be performed(27)
Biopsy rarely needed to differentiate between a Dupuytren’s nodule and a soft tissue tumor(27)
Laboratory tests: hemoglobin A1c or thyroid-stimulating  hormone (TSH) values(26)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether or not they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Are there any positions or movements that bring on or ease symptoms?
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (e.g., constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much). Pain usually signals a complication (e.g., excessive inflammation, hematoma, ischemic skin necrosis, wound infection)(23)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or(26) -Digital hematoma -Decreased digit vascularity -Granulation -Scar contracture -Inadvertent division of digital nerve or artery -Infection -Graft failure -CRPS(18) -DIP hyperextension deformity(23) -Transient paresthesia(23) -Persistent PIP flexion contracture(23) -Joint stiffness(23)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Document respiratory status, any use of supplemental oxygen Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes___ No___ -If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Ask if the patient has had this condition before, how often, and how it was resolved (if applicable). Is this a recurrence in a previously treated digit(s)? Has the patient had any other previous hand injury/dysfunction?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask the patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders. Diabetes mellitus, epilepsy, and chronic alcoholism are associated with Dupuytren’s contracture(17)
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask the patient about other symptoms he or she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Document patient’s occupation, any activities/sports, role within family
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: In a study conducted in Sweden, patients withusing a computer, baking, playing piano or trumpet, gardening, doing gymnastics, gripping a bicycle handlebar, activities that require manipulating objects with both hands, putting on a glove, washing and grooming, carpentry, shaking hands(8)
social and occupational history.living environment: Document with whom the patient lives (e.g., caregivers, family members). Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate ›Relevant tests and measures:  (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Document any use of adaptive equipment or assistive devices for functional activities. Assess for proper fit and useCircumferential or volumetric measurement of edema; measure both affected and unaffected hand
relevant tests and measures.functional mobility: Assess whether functional mobility is affected by inability to use handAssess fine motor coordination in functional activities –Jebsen Hand Function Test –9-hole  Peg Test
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Muscle strength –Assess pinch strength using digital pinch meter –Assess grip strength using hand dynamometer -Patients with Dupuytren’s contracture generally have good grip strength(17)
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Range of motion –Assess finger ROM using finger goniometer(22) –Total Active Mobility (TAM) – the sum of the active flexion in MP, PIP, and DIP joints minus the lack of active extension in the same joints(14) –Total Passive Mobility (TPM) – the sum of passive flexion in MP, PIP, and DIP joints minus the lack of passive extension in the same joints(14)Assess the patient’s ability to complete self-care  activities; note the amount of assistance needed –Manual Ability Measure (MAM-36)(6,7)
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Sensory testing –2-point  touch discrimination –Light touch (e.g., Semmes Weinstein monofilaments)
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosis –Disabilities of the Arm, Shoulder and Hand (DASH) Outcome Measure(14) -For more information on the DASH, see Clinical Review…Disabilities of the Arm, Shoulder and Hand (DASH) OutcomeT903177 –Quick DASH – shorter DASH assessment(4) -Based on a retrospective study of 69 patients who had Dupuytren’s surgery with pre- and postoperative Quick DASH scores, the Quick DASH is a valid patient-reported  outcome measure for Dupuytren’s surgery –Michigan Hand Outcomes Questionnaire (MHQ)(14) –Patient-Rated  Wrist and Hand Evaluation (PRWHE)(20) –Patient Evaluation Measure (PEM)(20)

other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment
Always follow surgeon’s guidelines for treatment, splinting/orthosis fabrication post-surgery
Exercise can increase flare-ups  of Dupuytren’s contracture(18)

While surgical corrections are often maintained at the MCP joint, recurrence at the PIP joint is common.(2) If CRPS develops, treatment should focus on CRPS. PROM is contraindicated because of pain; orthosis use may need to be discontinued temporarily until CRPS symptoms are controlled(23)
Keep incision from surgery clean and dry to prevent infection (unless otherwise specified)
Observe skin during orthosis use; watch for any redness or irritation

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Referral to occupational therapy to restore hand strength, mobility, and function; for postsurgical intervention
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out Callus formation(27) Nodule on flexor tendon(27) Camptodactyly – tight fascial bands on ulnar side of small finger(27) Soft tissue tumor(27) Tendon sheath cyst or ganglion(26) Fibroma(26) Lipoma(26) Epithelioid sarcoma(26) Neurofibroma(26) Palmar fascial disease, non-Dupuytren Stenosing tenosynovitis(26)
prognosis: Nonsurgical treatment is ineffective at reversing or stopping the progression of Dupuytren’s contracture(2)
Approximately 10% of patients will have regression of disease without treatment(27)
Recurrence more common in patients who are young at first presentation of symptoms(3)
Areas treated with full thickness skin grafts rarely develop recurrent disease(3)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Physician should any complications/infection occur Social services for home/equipment needs
other considerations: A “flare reaction” can occur 3–4 weeks post-surgery;  it consists of redness, swelling, pain, and stiffness(26)

Radiation therapy has been considered an intervention to treat Dupuytren’s contracture in the early stages. However, more studies are needed to compare the outcomes of radiation therapy with the standard treatment for Dupuytren’s contracture, as well as to determine any long-term  side effects(19)
treatment summary: Splinting/orthosis fabrication –Use of night-time  volar forearm-based  splint, wrist in neutral, fingers extended as much as possible, thumb in extension. Care should be taken to ensure that the position in the orthosis is not compromising the vascularity of the involved digit(s)
Strengthening –Initiated postoperatively, after wounds are healed, which is usually 3–4 weeks after primary closure, 4 weeks after skin grafting(3)

A passive motion machine used after palmar or digital fasciectomy for Dupuytren’s contracture does not offer an advantage over standard hand therapy for improving ROM(24) –Based on an RCT of 25 patients who underwent partial digital and/or palmar fasciectomy for Dupuytren’s contracture at the State University of New York Hand Center –Control group received postoperative hand therapy protocol –Intervention group received postoperative hand therapy protocol and passive motion machine –All patients assessed preoperatively, measurement of all passive and active joint motions –Hand therapy protocol -Static night extension splints/orthoses, worn for 6 months, modified as fingers gained more extension -Home therapy instruction -Gentle active ROM (AROM) exercises -Gentle passive flexion -Intrinsic and blocking exercises -Whirlpool -Edema control  -At 2 weeks postop: gentle passive extension exercises, scar massage –Intervention group was fitted for passive motion machine, adjusted to the end range of PROM that patient could tolerate; worn for 8–10  hours/day for 4 weeks –Postoperative assessments made at 1, 2, 4, 8, 12, 26, and ≥ 52 weeks –No significant difference between control and intervention group in flexion contracture at MP joint at any time period –Intervention group had 52% correction of contracture at PIP joint, while control group had 47% correction; this was not statistically significant

Researchers who conducted a study in the Netherlands designed to assess referral criteria following surgery for Dupuytren’s contracture found no difference in outcomes between patients appropriately referred for hand therapy and patients who were not referred(14) –Based on study of 38 patients in Groningen, the Netherlands; 21 patients were referred to hand therapy, while 17 were not referred –There were significant improvements on TAM/TPM, DASH Outcome Measure, and MHQ scores post-surgery –There were no statistically significant differences in outcome variables between those who received hand therapy and those who did not

Researchers who conducted a cohort study in Sweden designed to assess outcomes following surgery and hand therapy found that patients had decreased disability and functional ROM at 12 months after treatment(10) –Ninety patients with at least a 60˚ deficit in extension in at least one digit (either a single joint or as the sum of extension deficits in the MCP, PIP, and DIP joints) were included in the study –Patients were assessed preoperatively and at 3, 6, and 12 months after surgery. All patients were casted for 1 week. At 1 week a volar-based  orthosis was fabricated for each patient and the patient was instructed in ROM. The splint was used 24 hours/day (with removal for exercise) for 1 week, then only at nighttime for an additional 3–6months –Outcomes measured were AROM, sensibility (Semmes Weinstein monofilaments), scar pliability (subscale of the Vancouver Scar Scale), global expectations, satisfaction, the DASH Outcome Measure (Swedish version), safety and social issues regarding hand function, physical activity habits, and the EuroQol (EQ-5D) –The study found improvements in ROM regardless of number of fingers operated on. At the PIP joint, flexion contracture continued to be present at 12 months, but with no changes in sensation. Decreased scar pliability was found when multiple fingers were involved. Patient’s pre-surgery  expectations and post-surgery  reports of function were not different at 12 months; more involved digits correlated with a higher DASH Outcome Measure score, and patients’ physical activity habits were not changed over time

Clinical effectiveness of postoperative long-term  static night splinting/orthosis use on finger movement and hand function in patients with Dupuytren’s contracture is unproven(15) –Based on a systematic review of four research studies, none of which were RCTs –One study found that splinting resulted in fewer contractures –One study assessed finger extension, composite finger flexion, and hand function; the authors noted that splinting resulted in lower total finger flexion and greater disability in the hand at 3 months post-surgery

A Casting Motion to Mobilize Stiffness (CMMS) technique helps patients regain digital flexion and normal pattern of movement following Dupuytren’s fasciectomy(18) –Based on case studies of 4 patients in the United Kingdom who had Dupuytren’s fasciectomy, a nighttime extension splint, and active/passive joint mobilization exercises initiated 1 week postoperatively –All patients had complications of edema, multiple joint stiffness, adherent scar tissue –AROM of digits assessed before, during, and after cast application –Cast design: blocks MP joints in extension, but allows active PIP flexion; wrist in 20° extension –Cast exercises included mobilizing all the fingers actively with regular rest periods –Cast was reviewed and changed every 2–3 weeks –The CMMS treatment protocol lasted an average of 11 weeks, with 7 treatment sessions with therapist –All patients regained digital flexion and improved pattern of movement, did not compromise PIP extension

A hand protocol (exercises and splinting) for treating Dupuytren’s contracture can improve total digital extension and reduce activity limitations after a fasciectomy(8) –Based on a study of 30 patients in Greece with Dupuytren’s contracture who underwent fasciectomy (some with local flap, some with full thickness skin graft)  –After surgery, patients participated in an 8-week  program of isolated active flexion and extension of PIP and DID joints and full composite flexion –They also wore nighttime volar forearm splint (wrist in 10–20°  extension, MCP in 10–20°  flexion, IP joints in maximum extension without applying tension to wounds) for 24 weeks –Data collected included recurrence, identification of activities difficult to perform, self-reported  activity limitations using the DASH Outcome Measure, and total digital extension –Patients reported that their performance of activities improved (p < 0.001) after intervention –Patients had fewer symptoms or limitations to daily activities after intervention (p < 0.001) –Patients also had increased total digital extension after intervention (p < 0.001) –28 of 30 patients did not have a recurrence . maintenance or prevention: Patient compliance with orthosis use, home program to maximize recovery
Avoid modifiable risk factors (e.g., smoking, excessive alcohol intake)
